coredata.dc:title: Interaction-induced contributions from IR and raman forbidden bands: CS2 liquid mixtures
coredata.dc:creator: Pinan-Lucarre, J.P.
Dervil, E.
Loisel, J.
Dayan, E.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
In a previous paper, we have presented experimental and theoretical results on the intensity of forbidden IR and Raman bands of CS2 in liquid solutions. To reduce the disagreement observed on some Raman results, we consider changing the value of the derivative of the hyperpolarizability β with respect to the bending coordinate. We evaluate the different electrical contributions to the intensities and deduce that β′ for CS2 is about ten times larger than in CO2.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 161, number 4,5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEtTERS 22 September 1989 INTERACTION-INDUCED CONTRIBUTIONS FROM JR AND RAMAN FORBIDDEN BANDS: CS2 LIQUID MIXTURES J.P. PINAN-LUCARRE, E. DERVIL, J. LOISEL and E. DAYAN Service de Spectroscopie Moleculaire en Milieu Condense, Laboratoire de Recherches Physiques associe au CNRS, Universite Pierre et Marie Curie, 4 place .lussieu, Tour 22, 75252 Paris Cedex 05, France Receivcd 5 May 1989; in 1mal form 11 July 1989 In a previous paper, we have presented experimental and theoretical results on the intensity of forbidden IR and Raman bands of CS5 in liquid solutions. To reduce the disagreement observed on some Raman results, we consider changing the value of the derivative of the hyperpolarizability fi with respect to the bending coordinate. We evaluate the different electrical contributions to the intensities and deduce that /3 for CS2 is about ten times larger than in CO2. 1. Introduction In the liquid state, induced effects depend on the nature of the neighbouring molecules; the change in molecular symmetry thereby allowing the observa- tion of forbidden bands, In our previous work [1], we have presented experimental- and theoretical re- sults on the integrated intensities of the forbidden bands of CS2. The bands studied are y1 (L at 656 cm ) in JR absorption and u2 (fl at 394 cm-1) in Raman scattering; their intensity variations were observed for various solvent concentrations. The solvents were chosen among molecules having very different dipole moments (CH3CN, (CH3)2C0, CH3I, C5H10 and C6H12). This paper analyses the different contributions in- volved in the integrated intensities, particularly the electrical contributions. Attention is focused on CS2 mixed with CH3CN, CFI3I and C5H10. 2. Theoretical The integrated intensity is due to the total induced dipole moment or the total induced polarizability, 17. This quantity may be written as a sum of pair contributions between two identical CS2 molecules i j, and between a CS2 molecule and a solvent, as i j , represented in fig, 1. Fig. 1. Interaction configuration. Fora system composed of N1 active CS2 molecules and N2 solvent molecules and for the u mode cor- responding to the vibrational normal coordinate q~, we obtain Ni/Ni M fpv)= ~ ( ir + Z ~ )q~. The T t ) are interaction tensors between a pair of molecules. This treatment does not include overlap exchange and so we cannot account for short range induction mechanisms [3]. The model is usually truncated at order R5 or R 6 [4]. The symmetry of the active molecule leads to = ss= 0; we keep only the first non-zero terms of the expansion and obtain from relations (2), (3) and (1 X)p1 + Xp2. Jj,~ are structural integrals ob tained from pair distribution functions for two mol ecules i and). They have been numerically evaluated by Larsen et al. [6]. Three values of Po.i are con sidered: the first case corresponds to the close-packed configuration, the second is equal to 1 which gives rise to a cancellation between two- or three-particle contributions, and the third is an intermediate value corresponding to the CS2 solid density. (5) These assumptions permit the calculation of the IR and Raman integrated intensities. Within exper (6) imental error, the variations of these intensities ver sus volume concentration X are linear in the studied concentration range as shown in figs. 2 and 3. The integrated intensity I is given by [5] I=y ([H(X,1=0)]2) where y contains local field corrections depending on the sample refractive index and X is the solvent vol- ume fraction. In a preceding paper [I], in collaboration with G. Tarjus, the calculation of the IR and Raman forbid- den integrated intensities involved the following as- sumptions: (i) the sample is isotropic; (ii) the ro- tational, vibrational and translational terms are uncorrelated; (iii) vibrational and rotational de- phasing is negligible. The average values for the ro- tational and vibrational terms give rise to constant terms. Then, for the translational term we require the zero-time translational correlation functions 52 and 53 of two and three particles, respectively. S~ and S~ are conaentration-dependent and are calculated using a simple model: (i) The CS2-.solvent mixture is replaced by a one- component liquid of hard spheres. (ii) The S~ functions are obtained from 2 1.5 S~(X)= [(2l+l)a~]~52(+2(px(c3>X), Fig. 2. Experimental and theoretical IR values for the ratio I,,,~/ ! . ~. The two straight lines correspond to the extreme values of po. ( close-packed configuration, POEt = 1). Experimen- tal data: CB3CN (X); CH3I (+). where <o~ ) x is the concentration-dependent aver- age of the cube of the diameter of all constituents of the mixture and Px is the mixture density equal to 410 Contributions Solvent CH3CN CH3I C5H,0 ss 2~42 0.06 0.01 0 p 2 &r 0.00 0.00 A 2 a~ 0.04 0.04 0.00 A 2 at~ 0.08 0.28 0.30 fi A (a292) 0.00 0.00 0.00 structural factor 0.97 0.98 0.79 local tieldfactor (Ii ,) 0.34 0.22 0.37 theoretical slope 1.1 0.9 0.9 experinsentalslope 2.9 1.1 1.5 Contributions Solvent CH3CN CH3I a 2 p~2 a 2 9~2 o 2 cx? o 2 at2 ~ 9 (a282) structural factor Polo Wilson factor 7,25 0.48 0.05 0.08 0.11 0.97 0.19 0.84 0.48 0.05 0.30 0.12 0.98 0.07 theoretical slope experimental slope 6.8 7.4 0.5 0.9 Volume 161, number 4,5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEiTERS 22 September 1989 Table 2 Relative magnitude of the different contributions to the slopes predicted for the VV intensity of the t 2 Raman band of CS2 in various solvents. The values of the components of the A and fi tensors are those of CO2. (ps, is equal to the solid CS2 density) st~/Ipsre H3CN (~cs2 1.5 - . 11~~- r CH I + P552BGO5 0 .1 .2 .3 X (i) overlap effects, (ii) higher terms in the multi- pole expansion, (iii) translational rotational cou- pling, and the use of a simple liquid model. Conse- quently our rough assumptions appear reasonable. In Raman scattering, in addition to the molecular quantities above, we need the values of the com- ponents oftheA andss polarizability tensors. As for the CS2 molecule, A and fi are unknown and we have used ab initio values [15] derived for CO2. The calculations are made with the same assumptions de- scribed above. Table 2 gives the electrical contributions, the structural factor and the local field factor (Iv,). The structural factor is equal to 1 + (d/dX) [iC(X)/ 4(0)]. The local field factor takes into account in- teraction-induced contributions to the u1 Raman band which is used as a normalizing factor for the intensity ratios [16]. The comparison between the theoretical and ex- perimental results is quite good for non-polar sol- vents, but a large disagreement is observed in the case of the polar CH3CN. Indeed, table 2 shows that elec- trical contributions fi~2 M~2 and A 2_ ~*2 are neg- ligible in all cases. The theoretical slopes are prac- tically independent of the solvent polarity, contrary to the experimental results. That is why attention is focused here principally on the polar solvent. This discrepancy may be due to either the A 2 cr 2 or the fi 2 pt2 mechanism. If we suppose that the first mechanism is predominant, the intensities Fig. 3. Experimental and theoretical VV Raman values for the ratio .( ,,,/IP,,C. The two straight lines correspond to the extreme values of ~ (-. close-packed configuration, . Po. g = 1). Experimental data: CH3CN (X ); CH3I (+). Table I Relative magnitude of the different contributions to the slopes predicted for the intensity of the w1 IR band of CS2 in CH3CN and CH3I (pot is equal to the solid CS2 density) 3. Discussion In IR absorption, the molecular quantities re- quired to calculate the theoretical slope are all known [8 14]. We note that the solvent dipole moment plays an important part even at low volume concentrations. Fig. 2 shows good agreement between the experi- mental and calculated results, despite the neglect of 411 Contribution Solvent CH3CN CH3I C5H,0 fi 2_j~2 4.65 0.54 0 ss 2 of 0.30 0.31 0 A 2 a~ 0.03 0.05 0 A 2 a~2 0.06 0.24 0.25 ss A (a202) 0.01 0.01 0 structural factor 0.97 0.98 0.79 local field factor (h ,) 0.34 0.22 0.37 theoretical slope 3.7 0.t 0.9 experirnentalslope 2.9 1.1 1.5 Volume 161, number 4,5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEiTERS 22 September 1989 should become smaller from pure CS2 to CS2 mixed with CH3CN, the polarizability of CHJCN being less than that of CS2. But experience shows that this is not the case. Consequently, we deduce that the p~2 contribution is underestimated by taking the CO2 value for fi . This point has been noted also by Cox and Madden [4]. Thus we propose to multiply all Ill cc I components by a factor of 10 and we give the new calculated values for all electrical terms in table 3. It is noticeable that the /3 2 ~~*2 and ss 2 9*2 terms are predominant for the two polar solvents. More-, over the total slopes are in better agreement with ex- periment, principally in the case of CH3CN, as shown in fig. 3. For CH3I, taking into account the disparity in the experimental results, the agreement remains acceptable. Table 3 Relative magnitude of the different contributions to the slopes predicted for the VV intensity of the w2 Raman band of CS2 in various solvents, with fib2 = l0ss ~2 (ps., is equal to the solid CS2 density) In conclusion, we show here that the fi 2 /4*2 and 9*2 mechanisms play an important part in in- duced Raman effects. It would be interesting to per- form ab initio calculations of the A and fi com- ponents for CS2. References [1] E. Dayan, E. Dervil, I. Loiset and S.F. Pinan-Lucarre, Chem. Phys. 119 (1988) 107. head.ce:title: Interaction-induced contributions from IR and raman forbidden bands: CS2 liquid mixtures

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Service de Spectroscopie Moléculaire en Milieu Condensé, Laboratoire de Recherches Physiques associé au CNRS, Université Pierre et Marie Curie, 4 place Jussieu, Tour 22, 75252 Paris Cedex 05, France

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: In a previous paper, we have presented experimental and theoretical results on the intensity of forbidden IR and Raman bands of CS2 in liquid solutions. To reduce the disagreement observed on some Raman results, we consider changing the value of the derivative of the hyperpolarizability β with respect to the bending coordinate. We evaluate the different electrical contributions to the intensities and deduce that β′ for CS2 is about ten times larger than in CO2.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: J. Chem. Soc. Faraday Trans. I
